This Executive Summary contains Huntington Beach Utilities' administrative and operational programs to prevent chlorine-related accidents and reduce potential risks.  The regulated substance of concern and focus of this document is chlorine.  The following topics are addressed in this Executive Summary:

- Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
- Stationary Source and Regulated Substance
- Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
- Five Year Accident History
- Emergency Response Program
- Planned Changes to Improve Safety


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The Huntington Beach Utilities' senior management is not only committed to offer superior service, but to also maintain a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities.  The Water Supervisor administers the facilities safety and environmental policies. The Water Supervisor is responsible for various inspections of the facilities to ensure compliance, and oversees the entire safety and environmental programs.  These programs include safety, hazard communications, lockout/tagout, Hazardous Materials Emergency Business Plan, employee safety manuals, manufacturers documentation, Emergency Response, as well as the Risk Management Plan.


STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Huntington Beach Utilities chlorine sites are located throughout the City of Huntington Beach.  The immediate area surrounding each chlorine site is primarily residential.

The chlorine systems at Huntington Beach Utilities are used for the treatment of water used for domestic purposes.  The Huntington Beach Utilities water treatment system consists of five sites (Well Numbers 6, 7, 9, 10, and 13) that use two one-ton containers, three sites (Well Numbers 1 and 4, and Ellis/Edwards Hill Reservoir) that use 150-pound cylinders, four sites (Overmyer Reservoir and Well Numbers 3a, 5, a

nd 12) that use a combination of one 150-pound cylinder and one one-ton container.   In addition, Wells 1 and 4 store up to five 150-pound cylinders (750 pounds).  Chlorine gas leaving the one ton containers and/or 150 pound cylinders passes through a vacuum regulator to the ejector. Still under vacuum from the regulators, it is drawn to ejectors and mixed with water from the treatment process.
 
The chlorine systems are all operated under vacuum conditions. Each one-ton container and/or 150-pound cylinder is placed on a scale to allow Huntington Beach Utilities operators to plan ahead for ordering more chlorine and for the change out procedure.  Each one ton container is positioned so that the valves are vertically aligned.  A vacuum is created when process water is pumped through the ejectors.  This flow generates a vacuum (approximately 1-3 in. Hg) which opens the vacuum regulator.  Upon loss of vacuum in the line from any one ton container or 150-pound cylinder, a diaphragm in the vacuum regulator will close, stopping any chlorine from escaping. Any chlorine in the piping upon loss of vacuum will be drawn through the ejectors and into solution.

The chlorine gas is pulled from the one-ton containers and 150-pound cylinders to the vacuum regulator from the ejector.  The vacuum regulator is equipped with rotameters to monitor and control the flow of the chlorine gas.  From the chlorinators, the chlorine gas is injected directly into the well effluent and into the distribution system.

Once the chlorine leaves either the one-ton container or the 150 pound cylinder, the design of each process is very similar. 

TGO Technologies, Inc. is the developer and manufacturer of the "ChlorTainer", a vessel designed to contain the accidental release of liquid chlorine or chlorine gas.  The ChlorTainer is designed in accordance with ASME requirements and is capable of containing pressure releases of up to 250 psig and 300Â°F.  In the event of a failed cylinder, the system will

protect the operator as well as the external environment from exposure to toxic gas.  Since the gas is totally contained, it satisfies the code requirement as a treatment system and provides an alternate to the conventional method of mechanical scrubber systems.  If there was a small leak from any of the threaded connections, the paint on the connections will change color (from yellow/orange to red), immediately alerting the operator of a leak.

In the event of seismic activity, the systems at the Huntington Beach Utilities sites are equipped with a seismic switch that will put the system in a shutoff mode and automatically reset after the event. Should a pipeline containing toxic gas external to the vessel break, the amount of toxic gas released is limited to the amount of gas in the line.  The system will sense the break in the line and will not allow the chlorine to continue dispensing.  It will close isolation valves to seal the stored chlorine from adding to the release through the broken line.

In addition to the seismic switch, the ChlorTainers use nitrogen to power the fail-safe actuator that will automatically close the chlorine supply valve in the event of a chlorine leak outside the vessel. This fail-safe device ensures that all of the chlorine is contained within the vessel until it is safe to resume normal operation.

Back-up emergency and/or standby power is not required, as the ChlorTainer does not require power to contain gas releases.

In the event that a leak occurs in a stored cylinder, it can be contained by immediately placing the cylinder in the ChlorTainer.  The leaking cylinder may be removed after safely purging the ChlorTainer by processing the gas through the on-site chlorinator.


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

Huntington Beach Utilities has implemented this California Accidental Release Prevention Program to manage the handling of chlorine. In addition, common industry standards, policies,

and procedures are utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.

The chlorine well sites employed by the Huntington Beach Utilities are equipped with various system controls and status indicators intended to minimize potential chlorine related accidents and to allow operators to monitor system operations.  This monitoring system is comprised of excess flow valves, pressure indicators, as well as other system safeguards and methods for allowing facility operators to effectively monitor and control operations (daily log at each site).


FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no significant releases of chlorine at the any of the sites over the past five years (March 2006 - March 2011), that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 10 pounds or the state requirement mandating immediate reporting of any release or threatened release of a hazardous material.  There have been a couple of minor incidents that have occurred at chlorine treatment locations owned by Huntington Beach Utilities.  They are as follows:

- A small leak occurred at Well 13 on February 27, 2004.  At approximately 3 am, a contractor (Cambro Manufacturing Company) working one property adjacent to Huntington Beach Utilities Well 13 noticed a chlorine odor in the distribution center located directly to the west of the facility.  At about 2:30 am the Huntington Beach Fire Department arrived and administered first aid treatment to two Cambro Manufacturing Company employees.  At approximately 3:30 am the Fire Department HazMat notified Huntington Beach Utilities supervisors that a chlorine odor was detected from the facility and advised Huntington Beach Utilities to evacuate at approximately 4 am.  An all clear was given from the Fire Department at about 7 am.

The incident resulted from a small chlorine leak from one of the process lines for water treatment at the Peck Reservoir in Huntington Beach.  Huntington Beach Water Department personnel were on scene as the RP and advisory for HHM

46.  Once it was determined that a leak was present, zones were established for safety of public and response personnel.  HHM 46 personnel performed a level A entry to shut off the source of the leak and a second entry was made to confirm that all gas had dissipated and the building was deemed safe for occupancy to begin repairing the line.  The cause of the leak was from a faulty regulator, the regulator was replaced and exhaust tubing was redirected to expel inside the chlorine shed allowing for the detectors to alarm in the vent of another leak.  An estimated 5 pounds of chlorine was released to the atmosphere.

- A leak was discovered in February 2006 at Well Number 12.  The well runner visually checks the pressure gauge on the TGO ChlorTainer on a daily basis. The pressure within the TGO ChlorTainer increased to approximately 8 psig and it was determined that a leak had occurred in the annular space of the TGO ChlorTainer.  It is believed that the flex tubing attached to the container valve caused the leak.  Chlorine continued to be pulled from the 150 pound cylinder in order to exhaust the supply prior to removing the cylinder from the TGO ChlorTainer.  Chlorine gas was periodically vented from the annular space to water.  The Huntington Beach Utilities conducted a training exercise with Haz Mat and operators during which time the 150 pound cylinder was removed from the site.  No chlorine gas was believed to have been release to the outside air.


EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Huntington Beach Utilities has an emergency response plan in effect at the facility.  The Emergency Response Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of the PSM/RMP document.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives: 

1.)	To save lives.
2.)	To minimize and avoid injuries.
3.)	To protect the environment.
4.)	To minimize property damage.

Huntington Beach Utilities maintains a safety committee whose members include the emergency coordinators for

the facility.  The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility. 

The Plan also includes the Emergency training for all Huntington Beach Utilities employees. 

The Emergency Response Plan is reviewed and updated by the Huntington Beach Utilities responsible person at least once a year.  This Plan will be review and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM, RMP, and CalARP regulations, and to ensure that the plan is kept current.

The Huntington Beach Utilities has coordinated emergency response efforts with the local fire department, City of Huntington Beach Fire Department.  In the case of a chlorine-related emergency, it is the policy of Huntington Beach Utilities to evacuate the employees and to allow the fire department to respond to the emergenc(potentially with the assistance of trained facility personnel).


PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

A Process Hazard Analysis Addedum was conducted on March 23, 2011 to address changes made at Well #13.  Well #13 has two systems, one is the storage of 150-pound cylinders and the other is the chlorination system.  Huntington Beach Utilities removed all five (5) 150-pound chlorine cylinders from storage, replaced the two (2) 150-pound cylinders with two one-ton containers for the chlorination system, and increased in the maximum intended inventory for chlorine from 1,050 pounds to 4,000 pounds.  As the modification only involves a change in the vessel container and an increase in the maximum intended inventory for chlorine, the PSM/RMP Team determined that no new hazards were introduced (in the context of the 2009 Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation study).  Hence, a change in vessel container and an increase in the maximum intended inventory for chlorine does not invalidate the February 2009 Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation and no further ana

lysis is required. 

Huntington Beach Utilities has taken a pro-active approach to emergency response and safety at the chlorine well sites.  The annual emergency response drills are documented and mitigation measures to improve the Team's response are continuously being reviewed. Huntington Beach Utilities has implemented all recommendations from the initial technical studies, and will complete the recommendations from the Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation (February 2009) in a timely manner. 

The Process Safety Management team is planning to complete several items over the next year as their continued effort to provide a safe work environment for the facility employees.  These changes include the following items:

1.	Continue to train all employees in Process Safety Management and the facility Safety Plan/Programs.

2.	Continue to have employee involvement in Safety Plan Development.

3.	Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.

4.	Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.
